awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Tohono O'odham Language Center
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports a one-year planning grant to develop a Language Center at Tohono O'odham Community College (TOCC) in Sells Arizona. This planning grant will provide a springboard toward a larger grant for an Enterprise Advancement Center (TEA), a program offered by the Tribal Colleges and University Partnership Program at the National Science Foundation. This project is consistent with the goals of the Native American Languages Act, passed by the U.S. Congress in 1990, which enacted into policy the recognition of the unique status and importance of Native American languages. This center would serve the Tohono O'odham Nation as a clearing house for information about the Tohono O'odham language, an endangered Indigenous language spoken on both sides of the Arizona / Mexico border. The center will provide a support for teachers and students throughout the speaking community and a site for continued documentation and development of material resources for those seeking to teach or learn the language and / or for those with research interests related to the Tohono O'odham. Broader impacts also include the potential to enhance economic activity for a tribal nation, and to broaden participation for Native Americans, who are underrepresented in all the sciences, including linguistics.


When completed, the Tohono O'odham Language Center will provide a hub for all intellectual activity related to addressing the endangered status of the Tohono O'odham language. This includes building the capacity of students at TOCC and language workers throughout the community through training in language recording, language data management, language archiving, and in language-processing technology appropriate for community use in both language documentation and language teaching. There is also intellectual merit in the securing of appropriate academic resources and archival materials needed to support these activities. A center of this type will have language and language-related activities at its core, but will also be a center for community networking and media outreach. The broader impacts will ripple throughout the tribal college system at all levels, throughout the Tohono O'odham community and its related tribes, throughout other Indigenous communities in Arizona and around North America. Other stakeholders within Arizona Universities and state colleges, in tribal government and other entities charged with ensuring a future for Indigenous languages, will notice and feel the effects of centralizing language work for the betterment of all. Such a center is truly transformative and the vision is very much geared toward creating a replicable model, complete with state-of-the-art equipment and methods. There will be wide-ranging publicity from the planning stages onward as the research team gathers and shares information about the literal construction and the growing list of resources that will be included.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcome Report:

NSF Award #1934445

Project Title: Planning Grant: Tohono O’odham Language Center

Recipient Organization: Tohono O’odham Community College

Project Grant Period: 09/01/2019-12/31/2021

The Planning Grant supported research for the development of the O’odham Language Center. The idea for an O’odham Language Center grew out of a need to consolidate and strengthen efforts to revitalize the O’odham Language. There were 7 significant activities that were identified to provide critical support for the use of the language throughout the O’odham community; Resource Development, Language Center Functional Design, Language Documentation, Development of Protocols, Language Revitalization, Capacity Building, and Networking and Outreach. Research into these 7 activities resulted in the following outcomes.

Resource Development Outcome: Increased the availability of language resources accessible to the O’odham community by identifying O’odham language resources held in different archives, museums, and holdings of individual researchers. These language resources and materials will be acquired and secured in the Language Center’s Archive to create a clearing house of information and resources for the O’odham language. Identified existing language resources and materials that requires reviewing and updating to make them more accessible and available in a digital or online format.

Language Center Functional Design Outcome:  Developed and completed a final design for a language center to form a physical space for future work on the revitalization of the O’odham language. The physical structure, a 6,431 square foot adobe building, will house classrooms, offices, meeting rooms, study rooms, a language lab, a recording studio, an archive, and a space for the storage of documents to be used for curriculum purposes.  

Language Documentation Outcomes:  Administered a community wide comprehensive language survey to collect language status and language attitudes. Implemented an oral history project to collect the stories of elders in the community.  Processing a thirty-year old collection of O’odham related materials in the Doris Duke Oral History Project held at the Arizona State Museum.  Identified a demand for skilled individuals in language work and provided free training in language documentation and transcription practices. 

Development of Protocols Outcomes: Developed a Data Management Plan for access and use of language date held with the Language Center. Created a Media Release Form for use with oral history participants and created an advisory group to advise the Language Center on Tribal protocols.

Language Revitalization Outcomes:  Identified language immersion as the pedagogical model that shows the most favorable results in producing language speakers with a primary focus on programs that can serve young O’odham throughout the Nation such as language nests, immersion day care and youth immersion camps. Elders will be involved through a planned Master-Apprentice program which can support adult language learners.

Capacity Building Outcomes: Determined a need to establish satellite language centers in each of the twelve districts of the Tohono O’odham Nation. Identified the American Indian Language Development Institute at the University of Arizona as an organization that will provide sophisticated training related to language documentation, immersion techniques, data gathering, processing, management, and archiving. Established the Language Center as a training site for language and educational purposes. Established a relationship with the American Indian Higher Education Consortium and their Language Revitalization Iniwtiative Program.  The program provides support in technology and digital media resources as well as support in developing a long-term language revitalization strategy, along with an action plan to expand institutional capacities in the area of language teaching and revitalization.

Networking and Outreach Outcomes: Built connections with other groups and entities on the Tohono O’odham Nation that are engaged in language reclamation efforts. Established a partnership with the Arizona State Museum to process the O’odham related content in their oral history collection.  The American Indian Development Institute at the University of Arizona, will partner with the O’odham Language Center to offer their expertise on immersion strategies and other forms of language revitalization and documentation techniques. Established connections to the local school district to support their recent implementation of an enhanced language and culture program. Collaborating with the Tohono O’odham Nation Early Childhood Program to initiate a language immersion program. Built a relationship with the Salt River Pima/Maricopa Language Program to share information and strategies.

.
